text: 1. Next follows the Upanishad of the Sa m hitâ 2 .

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 2. The former half is the earth, the latter half the heaven, their union the air 3 , thus says Mâ n d ukeya; their union is the ether, thus did Mâkshavya teach it.

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 3. That air is not considered 4 independent 5 , therefore I do not agree with his (Mandûka's) son.

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 4. Verily, the two are the same, therefore air is

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: considered independent, thus says Âgastya. For it is the same, whether they say air or ether 1 .

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 5. So far with reference to deities (mythologically); now with reference to the body (physiologically):

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 6. The former half is speech, the latter half is mind, their union breath (prâ n a), thus says S ûravîra 2 Mâ n d ukeya.

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 7. But his eldest son said: The former half is mind, the latter half speech. For we first conceive with the mind indeed 3 , and then we utter with speech. Therefore the former half is indeed mind, the latter half speech, but their union is really breath.

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 8. Verily, it is the same with both, the father (Mâ n d ukeya) and the son 4 .

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 9. This (meditation as here described), joined 5 with mind, speech, and breath, is (like) a chariot drawn by two horses and one horse between them (prash t ivâhana).

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 10. And he who thus knows this union, becomes united with offspring, cattle, fame, glory of countenance, and the world of Svarga. He lives his full age.

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 11. Now all this comes from the Mâ n d ukeyas.

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 247:1 This last portion of the Upanishad is found in the MS. discovered by Dr. Bühler in Kashmir, and described by him in the journal of the Bombay Branch of the Royal Asiatic Society, 1877, p. 36. I have collated it, so far as it was possible to read it, many lines being either broken off altogether, or almost entirely obliterated.

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 247:2 Sa m hitâ is the sacred text in which all letters are closely joined. The joining together of two letters is called their sa m hitâ; the first letter of a joined group the pûrvarûpa (n.), the second the uttararûpa. For instance, in agnim î l e the m is pûrvarûpa, the î uttararûpa, and mî their sa m hitâ or union.

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 247:3 As in worshipping the S âlagrâma stone, we really worship Vishnu, so we ought to perceive the earth, the heaven, and the air when we pronounce the first and the second letters of a group, and that group itself.

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 247:4 Mene has here been taken as 3rd pers. sing. perf. passive. The commentator, however, explains it as an active verb, ni s k itavân.

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 247:5 Because it is included in the ether, not the ether in the air. Comm.

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
